discussion.content:
Explanation

The IP prefix is a member of the IPv4 address family. After the PE device learns the IP prefix, the PE converts it into a VPN-IPv4 prefix by combining it with an 8-byte route distinguisher (RD). The generated prefix is a member of the VPN-IPv4 address family. It uniquely identifies the customer address, even if the customer site is using globally nonunique (unregistered private) IP addresses.

Selected Answer: D
The given answer (D) is correct.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct
D is correct
The given answer is correct D
The given answer is correct

questions.question_text: What does the PE router convert the IPv4 prefix to within an MPLS VPN?

choices.D: VPN-IPv4 prefix combined with the 64-bit route distinguisher
choices.A: eBGP path association between the PE and CE sessions
choices.B: prefix that combines the ASN, PE router-id, and IP prefix
choices.C: 48-bit route combining the IP and PE router-id

choices.D: interface Tunnel0 description mGRE - DMVPN Tunnel ip address 10.0.0.1 255.255.255.0 ip nhrp map multicast dynamic ip nhrp network-id 1 tunnel source 10.0.0.1 tunnel destination 172.17.0.2 tunnel mode gre multipoint

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which interface configuration must be configured on the HUB router to enable MVPN with mGRE mode?

discussion.content: Tunnel source IP can NOT be the IP address of the tunnel interface. The tunnel source IP should be, in this case, the IP address of the WAN interface.

A - invalid tunnel ip-address.
B - invalid tunnel source ip-address.
C - multicast not enabled.
D - invalid tunnel source ip-address.

Apparently, everyone is choosing between the wrong ip-address and the missing multicast enable command.

Selected Answer: C
Cis correct

Selected Answer: C
The tunnel source can not be the tunnel itself. It has to be something else, such as a physical interface or the IP of a different interface.
The protocol in this case should also be gre multipoint since we are dealing with a DMVPN.

The correct answer is C.

Selected Answer: C
The source tunnel interface can't be the Tunnel address itself

questions.question_text: How are MPLS Layer 3 VPN services deployed?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct

The MPLS LDP Autoconfiguration feature enables you to globally enable Label Distribution Protocol (LDP)
on every interface associated with an Interior Gateway Protocol (IGP) instance. This feature is supported on
Open Shortest Path First (OSPF) and Intermediate System-to-Intermediate System (IS-IS) IGPs. It provides
a means to block LDP from being enabled on interfaces that you do not want enabled. The goal of the MPLS
LDP Autoconfiguration feature is to make configuration easier, faster, and error free.
The given answer is correct
The given answer is correct

questions.question_text: Which IGPs are supported by the MPLS LDP autoconfiguration feature?

Refer to the exhibit.
//IMG//

An engineer must establish multipoint GRE tunnels between hub router R6 and branch routers R1, R2, and R3.
Which configuration accomplishes this task on R1?

choices.A: interface Tunnel 1 ip address 192.168.1.1 255.255.255.0 tunnel source e0/0 tunnel mode gre multipoint ip nhrp nhs 192.168.1.6 ip nhrp map 192.168.1.6 192.1.10.1 ip nhrp map 192.168.1.2 192.1.20.2 ip nhrp map 192.168.1.3 192.1.30.3
choices.C: interface Tunnel 1 ip address 192.168.1.1 255.255.255.0 tunnel source e0/0 tunnel mode gre multipoint ip nhrp network-id 1 ip nhrp nhs 192.168.1.6 ip nhrp map 192.168.1.6 192.1.10.6
choices.B: interface Tunnel 1 ip address 192.168.1.1 255.255.255.0 tunnel source e0/1 tunnel mode gre multipoint ip nhrp nhs 192.168.1.6 ip nhrp map 192. 168.1.6 192.1.10.6
choices.D: interface Tunnel 1 ip address 192.168.1.1 255. 255.255.0 tunnel source e0/1 tunnel mode gre multipoint ip nhrp network-id 1 ip nhrp nhs 192.168.1.6 ip nhrp map 192.168.1.6 192.1.10.1 ip nhrp map 192.168.1.2 192.1.20.2 ip nhrp map 192.168.1.3 192.1.30.3

tunnel source e0/0 
tunnel mode gre multipoint 
ip nhrp nhs 192.168.1.6 
ip nhrp map 192.168.1.6 192.1.10.1 
ip nhrp map 192.168.1.2 192.1.20.2 
ip nhrp map 192.168.1.3 192.1.30.3

tunnel source e0/1 
tunnel mode gre multipoint 
ip nhrp nhs 192.168.1.6 
ip nhrp map 192. 168.1.6 192.1.10.6
C. 
interface Tunnel 1 
ip address 192.168.1.1 255.255.255.0 
tunnel source e0/0 
tunnel mode gre multipoint 
ip nhrp network-id 1 
ip nhrp nhs 192.168.1.6 
ip nhrp map 192.168.1.6 192.1.10.6

tunnel mode gre multipoint 
ip nhrp network-id 1 
ip nhrp nhs 192.168.1.6 
ip nhrp map 192.168.1.6 192.1.10.1 
ip nhrp map 192.168.1.2 192.1.20.2 
ip nhrp map 192.168.1.3 192.1.30.3

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

comments.content: All DMVPN spoke/hub can have different network-id. network-id is locally significant. We set uo tunnels through mappings.
To clarify: The network-id's can be different. But they must be initiated to start the nhrp protocol.
B is not wrong because of the missing network ID command, but because it uses e0/1 as tunnel source on R1 and it should be e0/0

discussion.content:
C is correct
B doesn't have a network iD command.
C is correct
